But in my view, the shifts in U.S. policy have </info> <info>not been well considered or well understood, in part because most of </info> <info>the relevant scholars, policymakers, and funding derive from a single </info> <info>perspective--that of the European Union.</info> <info> So in my view, the U.S. does not need a new policy toward Europe. </info> <info>It already has a new policy toward Europe. And it's had a new policy </info> <info>toward Europe since the end of the cold war. It needs to return to its </info> <info>former policy, from which it has thoughtlessly strayed. Inevitably, </info> <info>this briefing, like any discussion of Europe, raises the question of </info> <info>populism. I'm not entirely sure what is meant by the term populism, </info> <info>except that it is obviously used to describe parties, movements, and </info> <info>beliefs that the speaker dislikes. It is a negative term.</info> <info> At the level of politics, what is happening is that in many </info> <info>European nations--except for Britain, interestingly--established </info> <info>parties on the left in particular, but also on the right, are losing </info> <info>votes to new parties which are often described as populist or </info> <info>nationalist. It's important to understand why this is happening. I've </info> <info>been struck over the past several years by the relatively uncurious </info> <info>approach that's been taken toward the rise of the new parties and the </info> <info>decline of the old ones. The phenomena, in my view, is condemned more </info> <info>often than it is analyzed.</info> <info> Sometimes the explanation that's offered is that it's all the fault </info> <info>of the Russians. I have been a vehement opponent of the Russian regime, </info> <info>and a great many pieces on it published, but in my view blaming the </info> <info>Russians is so simplistic an explanation that it barely merits a </info> <info>rebuttal. It should be obvious that when large numbers of people vote </info> <info>for new parties, they are doing so because the old parties do not meet </info> <info>their needs. If lots of people did not vote for the new parties, there </info> <info>would be no rise of populism to worry about. It should be equally </info> <info>obvious that the old consensus and the analytic and policy support for </info> <info>it from the U.S. are equally faulty. After all, if that consensus had </info> <info>been genuinely satisfactory, it would be now receiving more support </info> <info>from the European publics.</info> <info> One problem is the relative narrowness of the political consensus </info> <info>in Europe. You don't have to go very far on the left, or especially on </info> <info>the right, before you fall outside the European political consensus. In </info> <info>these circumstances, anyone who disagrees with a substantial part of </info> <info>that consensus is going to have to look for a new party to vote for. </info> <info>And given that support for the European Union and for ever-deeper </info> <info>integration are a core part of the elite European political consensus, </info> <info>it's inevitable that a good deal of the rebellion against it is going </info> <info>to be associated with nationalism.</info> <info> Now, nationalism is a dirty word in Europe. That's because </info> <info>nationalism has been tarred by association with Nazism. Precisely why </info> <info>Adolf Hitler, who was a racist imperialist, is now regarded as a </info> <info>nationalist, while the nationalists in Poland, France, and Britain who </info> <info>resisted Hitler and fought to restore or save their political </info> <info>independence are treated as the heroes of Europe's anti-nationalist </info> <info>rebirth is an interesting question. But the broader fact is this: Every </info> <info>single stable democracy in the world--every one of them--grew out of a </info> <info>national state and was fortified by a sense of nationalism. Without </info> <info>nationalism, there is no political community, and without political </info> <info>community there can be no democracy.</info> <info> This is not an original idea on my part. Philosophers from Adam </info> <info>Smith to John Stuart Mill regarded what I have just said as an absolute </info> <info>commonplace. Historians of almost every European nation--I'm thinking </info> <info>of my first advisor at Yale, Linda Colley, who wrote about Britain, to </info> <info>the distinguished historian of France, Eugene Weber--have pointed out </info> <info>the importance of a felt sense of national identity to the making of a </info> <info>political nation--all of these historians have also pointed out </info> <info>something else. National identity is not inherent. Babies are not born </info> <info>French or Polish. National identity is learned and constructed. In </info> <info>other words, you do not just--in Eugene Weber's phrase--make peasants </info> <info>into Frenchmen once. You have to do it every generation.</info> <info> And you have to do it with immigrants, too. Too many in Europe </info> <info>believe that Europe can rest forever on the nation-making achievements </info> <info>of past generations, or even that it should degrade those achievements </info> <info>by denigrating nationalism for the sake of a shallowly rooted </info> <info>Europeanism. This is a fundamental error. Nations are not made forever. </info> <info>And if they are not being continuously remade, they are being </info> <info>destroyed.</info> <info> I would not, myself, say that nationalism is a good thing. Like any </info> <info>kind of group identity, it offends against God's truth that we are all </info> <info>individuals. Nor would I say that all nationalism in Europe will </info> <info>necessarily be for the best. You cannot spend 70 years equating </info> <info>nationalism with illiberalism and Adolf Hitler and then be shocked that </info> <info>the belief that you have demonized is represented at times by </info> <info>illiberals. Europe has made its bed and it's going to have to lie in </info> <info>it. If liberals do not own nationalism, it will inevitably become the </info> <info>property of illiberals.</info> <info> But I would say that nationalism is a necessary thing, and that if </info> <info>you don't have it or if you try to repress it, its space will be filled </info> <info>by other kinds of group identities that are fundamentally incompatible </info> <info>with democracy. In other words, I regard nationalism as an important </info> <info>and necessary force. I disagree with those who argue that nationalism </info> <info>was responsible for Europe's fall. I agree, instead, with Adam Smith; </info> <info>Europe rose because it was divided into competing units. Nationalism as </info> <info>the cause of Europe's rise, not Europe's fall.</info> <info> So part of the reason for the rise of populism in Europe is that a </info> <info>narrow and anti-national elite political consensus left no space for </info> <info>nationalism. Nationalism has therefore made its own space. But this is </info> <info>only part of what's going on. Another part are specific policy errors </info> <info>that Europe has made and that the U.S. has, especially since the end of </info> <info>the cold war, indulged and supported. If we go back to the immediate </info> <info>post-1945 years, we will see that the U.S. approach to stabilizing and </info> <info>democratizing Europe, or at least Western Europe, rested heavily on the </info> <info>belief that democracy cannot exist without reasonably high and steady </info> <info>levels of economic growth. At the least, there can be no Great </info> <info>Depressions.</info> <info> Thus, all of the U.S. initiatives in post-war Europe--from the </info> <info>European Bank for Reconstruction and Development--we now call it the </info> <info>World Bank--to the IMF, to the Marshall Plan, to the GATT--it's now the </info> <info>World Trade Organization--and, yes, even NATO--were fundamentally </info> <info>economic. This belief drew on a diagnosis about the causes of the rise </info> <info>of the Nazis and the origins of the Second World War, which was </info> <info>fundamentally liberal. What do we do now? We </info> <info>do precisely the opposite. The apple of the EU's eye is the euro, </info> <info>which, as the Obama administration agreed during the euro crisis, must </info> <info>be preserved at all costs. The EU therefore pushes the forces of change </info> <info>away from its economic system and into the political systems of its </info> <info>member nations--such as Greece and now Italy. And the U.S. supports the </info> <info>EU in this error. We now prioritize economics over politics. After </info> <info>1945, we did precisely the reverse.</info> <info> The EU likes to boast that the European economic model is different </info> <info>from that of the United States. Democracies cannot tolerate persistently high levels of </info> <info>unemployment. It is a sure bet that voting publics will react to low </info> <info>growth and high unemployment somehow, likely by blaming the parties in </info> <info>power and voting for new ones.</info> <info> The first major error we have made is, therefore, economic. The </info> <info>second major error we and Europe have made is to neglect security. This is the culmination </info> <info>of a long-held American wish, one expressed almost as vehemently by </info> <info>President Eisenhower as was it was by Presidents Obama or Trump. The point of EU defense </info> <info>initiatives is not to improve Europe's defenses.
